Award.AwardTitle: Total Tomography of III-V Non-Planar Heterostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: Semiconducting materials, particularly alloys composed of group III and group V elements, are useful for converting electrical energy to light in light-emitting diode devices. Different III-V semiconductors can be combined in heterostructures to make devices smaller and the energy conversion processes more efficient. The project develops fundamental understanding of how semiconducting alloys in nanowire form can be best arranged to control the flow of electrical energy and generate light in the infrared portion of the spectrum. This understanding contributes to the development of on-chip photonic interconnects that overcome the bottleneck in the speed of information transfer between computer chips that process huge volumes of information in cloud computing. The project trains graduate students in cutting-edge three-dimensional characterization methods at Northwestern and in national laboratories. Web-based interactive case studies are used to disseminate advances in these characterization methods, which can accelerate the development of new electronic and photonic technologies.

Technical description: The goal of the project is to correlate the composition, strain, and electronic structure of group III-As nanowire core-shell heterostructures in three dimensions to understand how interactions between composition and strain influence nanostructure growth and optoelectronic properties. Atom probe tomography is used to measure three-dimensional composition fields with nanoscale resolution. Based on these composition data, finite element models of relaxed physical structure are created to extract three-dimensional strain information from single nanowire x-ray imaging and diffraction studies. Combined strain and composition data, including dopant distributions accessible only by atom probe tomography, are used to model electronic and optical properties and identify materials factors that limit the performance of III-As core-shell nanowires as infrared light emitting diodes and lasers. Single nanowire Raman, photoluminescence, and electrical measurements are used to spatially map strain, carrier concentrations and lifetimes, and the band offsets that establish confinement potentials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconducting materials, particularly alloys composed of group III and group V elements, are useful for converting electrical energy to light in light-emitting diode devices. Different III-V semiconductors can be combined in heterostructures to make devices smaller and the energy conversion processes more efficient. The project developed fundamental understanding of how one can arrange semiconducting alloys in the form of nanowires to control the flow of electrical charges and generate light with useful characteristics in the infrared portion of the spectrum. This understanding can contribute to the development of on-chip photonic interconnects that overcome the bottleneck in the speed of information transfer between computer chips that process huge volumes of information in cloud computing. In addition, the project demonstrated how electrical charge confinement could be influenced by the structure of nanowire crystals, providing a new engineering degree of freedom that may be useful in producing sources of light for quantum communication.

The intellectual merit of the work lies in the detailed understanding of how several materials characteristics, including the composition, strain, and crystal structure, influence the electrical and optical properties of semiconductor nanostructures. To gain detailed understanding of each of these factors at the nanometer lengthscale, the project applied two very advanced methodologies- atom probe tomography and coherent x-ray nanodiffraction- in concert for the first time, providing insights that were previously unavailable. Atom probe tomography was used to map the positions of very dilute impurities, known as dopants, that are necessary to produce useful devices in semiconductors. The project discovered that the conditions that are optimized for nanostructure formation may lead to unintentional variations in the concentrations of dopant atoms. International collaborators in Germany were engaged to produce the high-quality materials, characterize properties, and create models that could explain the structure-property relationships. Materials growth processes were also optimized based on the feedback from atom probe tomography and x-ray diffraction.

The project produced broader impacts related to the development of cutting-edge technologies and training a future workforce to maintain domestic competitiveness in industries relevant to national defense and information technology. Specifically, the project trained graduate students in the complementary methods of atom probe tomography and coherent x-ray diffraction, while developing modeling methodologies needed for such correlated measurements. The results and methods to achieve them were shared with scientists at Argonne National Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory, as well as international synchrotron facilities, through collaborations and conferences. In addition, a major review article was published describing how to apply these methods to nanostructures in general. In this way, the research helped overcome significant barriers to the application of advanced methods in both basic and applied research. Both graduate students on the project are female, and the lead graduate student has engaged in multiple outreach efforts aimed at encouraging girls and women to pursue careers in science.
